item.title: Fortnite: Hot Air Balloon Guide (Locations, Route)
item.description:
Epic Games made major changes to Fortnite when Chapter 7 went live. Whenever there is a Fortnite chapter renewal, players are given a brand-new island and map to explore, and they're introduced to an array of mechanics.

As soon as players drop onto it for the first time, players will notice that the seventh Battle Royale island has several hot air balloons floating around it. This will intrigue many players, and they will feel compelled to investigate them. This guide tells players everything they need to know about hot air balloons in Fortnite .

How Do Hot Air Balloons Work in Fortnite?

Hot air balloons can be seen floating all around the Battle Royale island in Fortnite . The air balloons continuously follow the same path, and players can ride them to easily travel from one stop to the next.

If gamers are close to the hot air balloons' route, they'll be able to easily spot them by looking up. Alternatively, they can simply open their map and take a look at where they are - each hot air balloon's icon will move as they do.

Hot air balloons have two containers for players to loot. So, even if players don't want to hop on for a ride, they're worth checking for goodies that they might have inside. Additionally, gamers can get on a balloon to easily get high ground over anyone they might fly over. However, they must be careful, as they only have 2,500 HP, so they can be shot down fairly quickly.

How to Use Hot Air Balloons

Hot Air Balloon Route

Hot air balloons are a great way for players to move around the map. It takes a hot air balloon three minutes to reach the next stop. Each hot air balloon stop has a waiting room, where players can see how long they have to wait until the next one arrives at the station.

There are four air balloons in Fortnite and five balloon stations. Here are their routes and the location of each station:

  • Southeast of Wonkeeland
  • West of Sandy Strip
  • Northeast of Sus Studios
  • North of Battlewood Boulevard
  • East of Bumpy Bay

item.title: Best FPS Games That Let You Customize Everything About Your Guns
item.description:
FPS games would be nothing without the guns within them. It doesn't matter if players are using realistic military rifles or futuristic laser weapons; the armaments they have access to play a crucial role in dictating how the game feels, and when they are able to modify and customize them, the whole experience feels a lot more enjoyable.

A lot of games take the basic route of giving players a range of guns to choose from, but a few go above and beyond, letting them change virtually every aspect they could ever need to. From cosmetics to the actual mechanics of the weaponry, these FPS games show how important customization is in keeping players happy and invested for more than a single match.

Escape From Tarkov

Realistic Military Weaponry

Details:

  • Thousands of builds through modular parts
  • Attachments meaningfully affect weapon stats

Escape From Tarkov offers one of the deepest weapon modification systems ever created in an FPS. Nearly every component from the barrel to the stock to the scope can be swapped or tuned to fit the player's needs and playstyle.

What sets the game apart, however, is how impactful the attachments are in the actual gameplay. An unmodded gun will feel sloppy and awkward, whereas by adding just a few extra features, players can transform an average rifle into a powerful killing machine that can be tailored to whatever use case is needed at the time.

Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare 3

More Mods Than Ever

Details:

  • Weapon slots with dedicated use cases
  • Night and day difference between attachments

Call of Duty has always allowed players to customize a large range of weapons however they choose, but in MW3 , things are taken to a whole new level. The basic options like magazine size and scopes remain, yet beyond the base systems lies even more depth for players to discover.

The aftermarket parts and conversion kits bring with them far more drastic changes that alter how guns function at a fundamental level. Burst weapons can become fully automatic, and heavy LMGs can be made mobile, giving individual weapons a whole new playstyle that can be altered even further with the original set of attachments.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands

A Whole Toy Box Of Guns To Try

Details:

  • Extensive attachment across real-world weapons
  • Tactical uses for each and every modification

Ghost Recon Wildlands embraces tactical flexibility through a robust customization framework that encourages players to adapt to different mission scenarios. Players can modify all the weapon classes with adjustable scopes, suppressors, stocks, and under-barrel attachments, each serving a specific purpose across the various areas.

Normally, simple changes like a silencer don't feel all that impactful. Here, however, a heavy weapon can suddenly be a viable infiltration option, and long-range weapons can easily be used in more close-quarters situations, transforming weapon close-quarters into hybrid armaments that can be tailored to the circumstance and needs at hand.

Payday 2

Turning Bank-robbing Into A Playground

Details:

  • Anything from perks to specific ammo types
  • Other factors, like concealment, affect weapon choices

Payday 2 turns gun customization into a far more in-depth thought exercise that tests how creative players can be for each mission. Every weapon can be dissected and outfitted with a wide range of attachments that alter how it handles during the various chaotic robberies, some affecting stopping power, and others aiding in a more stealth-oriented approach.

Because each heist demands a different approach, custom loadouts become integral to success. High-concealment pistols support quieter, more calculated infiltrations, while modded LMGs and shotguns dominate full-alert firefights, allowing players to make use of a range of weapons without ever feeling forced into one playstyle or another.

Mothergunship

Building Guns From The Ground Up

Details:

  • A literal gun creation mechanic
  • Absurd combinations of attachments, only limited by player creativity

Mothergunship delivers an incredibly imaginative approach to weapon customization. Instead of swapping attachments, players craft guns from scratch, linking components in outlandish configurations, giving them a huge range of options in terms of firepower and killing potential.

Multi-barrel laser arrays, rocket-shotgun hybrids, and bullet-spewing monstrosities are all possible within the system. Rather than being stuck to using a few specific guns, players are instead encouraged to be as creative as possible to fully unlock the true explosive potential of the game.

Fallout 4

Crafting Whatever You Can

Details:

  • Range of unique customization and mechanical options
  • Specific weapons can be transformed into entirely different types

Fallout 4s crafting system treats weapons as tools that evolve over the course of an entire playthrough. Single rifles can be transformed into snipers, or pistols can become automatic bullet storms, but the key lies in the range of options and the amount of freedom that players have right from the start.

There is also a lot of breadth in terms of functional flexibility, as different enemy types and encounters will demand a certain weapon in order to take them down. The whole experience allows for a huge amount of experimentation, with virtually any build being viable and having a use case within the wasteland.

Ground Branch

Creating The Perfect Armament

Details:

  • Real-time attachment placement
  • Weapon behavior is dictated by weight and balance

Ground Branch's weapon customization system feels more like a gun shop simulator than a feature in an FPS game. Players are able to slot attachments like scopes and laser sights anywhere along the weapon's rails, giving them access to a huge range of options that no other game has.

The impact of each attachment is also far more complex than just basic stat upgrades. Factors like weapon weight come into play, making individual placements feel more realistic, and rather than just throwing on the best attachments onto each weapon, circumstances become the main deciding factor.

item.title: 'Resolved' The Marathon Art Plagiarism Controversy is Over
item.description:
Almost seven months after the initial claim was made, artist Antireal has taken to Twitter to announce that they have reached an agreement with Marathon developer Bungie and its parent company, Sony, in regards to a serious plagiarism issue. After finding huge success with the Destiny franchise, Bungie is now attempting to reboot its Marathon shooter from 1994, but the studio suffered a huge setback earlier this year when an artist came forward with accusations that the title was using assets from them without prior permission.

Since its reveal in 2023, Marathon has experienced numerous controversies, with its biggest undoubtedly being the discovery that Bungie had used assets from an artist without their permission. The claim was first made by Antireal back in May of this year, when they took to Twitter and noted how the alpha build of Bungie's new shooter was using assets that were directly lifted from posters the artist had designed in 2017. Antireal provided numerous examples of the alleged plagiarism, which Bungie then responded to less than 24 hours later.

Shortly after the accusation was made, Bungie responded to Marathon 's plagiarism concerns, stating that it was investigating the issue. The statement explains how a former Bungie artist included Antireal's designs in a texture sheet that was then used in-game. The studio says it was reviewing how the oversight occurred and that it takes matters such as these very seriously, also noting that it had reached out to the original artist in order to discuss the issue further and "do right" by them. Bungie said it values the creativity and dedication of all artists and thanked the community for bringing the issue to its attention.

Marathon's Plagiarism Incident Has Been Resolved Privately

Following Bungie's statement on the matter, very little was said over the last few months. However, that has now changed, as artist Antireal has once again taken to Twitter to confirm that the involved parties have reached a resolution. " The Marathon art issue has been resolved with Bungie and Sony Interactive Entertainment to my satisfaction," they said in a new post on December 2. No further details on the agreement were shared, but it seems as though the matter was resolved privately between all of those involved. As for whether the artist received compensation, in-game credit for their work, or both, remains unknown. Neither Bungie nor Sony has issued a statement on the resolution at the time of writing this article.

Although the issue was between Antireal and Bungie, the Marathon and Destiny studio was acquired by Sony in 2022, making the matter one for Sony Interactive Entertainment, too. Then, earlier this year, Sony's Chief Financial Officer Lin Tao said the company intends to take more control over Bungie as it plans to fully integrate the studio with PlayStation Studios. Despite this statement, Marathon will still be a multiplatform release, set to arrive on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S, and PC at a currently unconfirmed date.

Plagiarism issues aside, Marathon has also suffered numerous other setbacks since its reveal two years ago. Bungie's new first-person shooter was initially set to release on September 23, but Marathon received an indefinite delay just three months before it was set to go live. The delay came after largely negative player feedback during a closed alpha test earlier in the year, which prompted the studio to make a wide array of improvements. Although the game hasn't been cancelled, it does appear to be undergoing some major changes, which is why the studio hasn't committed to a new release date as of writing. Bungie says it intends to make AI encounters more challenging and engaging, as well as make runs more rewarding with new types of loot and dynamic events. Combat is also being reworked, as well as an increase to the game's narrative and environmental storytelling.

item.title: How Metroid Prime 4 Reviews Compare to the Other Games in the Series
item.description:
Reviews for Metroid Prime 4: Beyond are rolling in, and so far, the game is the lowest-rated in the series. The news may sting a bit for some fans in light of the wait for the title, which went so quiet for so long that it became something of a meme within the gaming community. While Metroid Prime 4: Beyond may be the most anticipated in the franchise, it seems many critics don't believe it's the best.

Some fans have gotten their Metroid Prime 4 copies early, but everyone not lucky enough to be near a store that put the game on shelves prematurely can play it on December 4. The hype for that release date is undeniable, with Metroid fans having waited for the day since 2017, back before the original Switch and when E3 was still running. Times have changed since then, but many still hold the Metroid Prime series in high regard, so the newest entry has a lot to live up to. If early scores are anything to go by, Metroid Prime 4 may not have cleared the bar as well as some had hoped.

All Mainline Metroid Prime Games by Metacritic Score

At the time of writing, Metroid Prime 4: Beyond is sitting at an 81 on Metacritic, based on 64 reviews, making it the lowest-rated mainline Metroid Prime game. While an 81 is still a favorable number, it does represent the biggest drop in average critic reviews the series has seen to date, being nine points shy of Metroid Prime 3: Corruption . There is still time for more reviews to come in and improve the newest game's overall rating, but falling so short after an 18-year gap between Metroid Prime 4 and the third game is not what fans likely wanted to see.

Metroid Prime Remastered holds a 94 on Metacritic, placing it just shy of the original but higher than the rest of the franchise.

With its current score, Metroid Prime 4 continues a trend for the mainline Metroid Prime games, which have decreased in average ratings with each subsequent release. Unsurprisingly, the beloved first game in the series holds the highest score. Additionally, some fans argue that 2023's Metroid Prime Remastered is the best Metroid Prime game.

Looking beyond the main games, Metroid Prime 4 does rank above some previous entries. While Metroid Prime Hunters sits above it at an 85, Metroid Prime Pinball and Metroid Prime: Federation Force scored lower, earning a 79 and a 64 average critic score, respectively. It's also worth noting that user reviews aren't available yet, although so far, these might follow the same overall trend as Metroid Prime 's critic reviews. Many of those who got to preview the game found Metroid Prime 4 's sidekick annoying, which has worried some fans, but it's impossible to say how most people will feel about the title until they can play it for themselves.

Fans will be able to make their own judgments about the game before long. Beyond that, it's rumored that Metroid Prime 5 will begin development soon, though it's way too early to make any sort of prediction about that game or how critics and players will receive it. Hopefully, the wait for the next one won't be quite as long as the gap between the third and fourth games, but for now, Metroid fans have Metroid Prime 4 to look forward to, even if it hasn't been reviewed as well as previous entries.
